The concerns over ecological collapse are completely overblown. All of the species that eat mosquitoes (e.g. dragonflies, bats, birds, etc.) also eat a lot of other species. Removing mosquitoes from an ecosystem would (at most) produce minor shifts in the population sizes and distribution of the mosquito predators. And that makes sense - relying on a parasitic species as your sole source of food would be a terrible choice, evolutionarily speaking. The energy contained within the biomass of any animal parasite species is necessarily far, far less than that contained in the host, which is itself already far less than that contained in the host's source of energy. It's hard to be an ecologically important species at higher trophic levels.

I confess, I'm actually less concerned about the things mosquitos feed on (like us) than I am about the things that feed on the mosquitos, because that can affect A LOT of creatures. I used to teach a kids' science program that used mosquitos as an example of bioaccumulation that went mosquito > dragonfly > songbird > falcon, and that was only ONE example. I live in western Canada, and our little brown bats are tiny adorable mosquito-eating MACHINES!

1:00 Guys... come on. This is the second time I've had to leave a comment like this. I'm sure you're not intending to prop up transphobic misinformation, but this is just flat out wrong: the exact thing you immediately go on to "contrast" in mosquitos is true in humans too! Our sexual development is governed by a single gene, SRY, which (usually) lives on the Y chromosome. It expresses early in development to determine whether you grow ovaries or testes, and subsequently your chromosomes have NOTHING AT ALL to do with your physical sex.

In fact, SRY can be transposed to the X chromosome, or fail to express on the Y -- which results in XX men, and XY women, who develop normally and neither they nor anybody else will be aware there's anything different about them without an actual genetic test!

It's exceedingly important not to get this wrong, because the idea that trans people are always at some level our assigned birth sex is the basis of immense institutional transphobia. In fact, it only takes a few months of hormone therapy for all the body's systems to adapt and behave as though they'd always been in that environment; because genetically, we've all got the blueprints for both modes of sexual expression. Major structures may not change shape, but they all start acting like their developmental counterparts (or in the case of the gonads themselves, just shut down and do nothing).

Not only do mositos thin the Herd and thus strengthen the specie resilience, but they also feed bats and other animals. Most importantly they allow cross specie gene swapping and are the mechanism for evolution jumps and leaps forward. The placenta is an example of a viral gene insertion that would not be around if mosquitoes were not around.   The genetic diversity of species allows for greater ability to survive as a specie as climate suddenly swings, as has constantly swung within spans of 40 years for the past billion years.

People like to complain about humans "messing with nature". But it seems like messing with nature in some way or another is inevitable. And Id say there's a higher probability of doing something thats beneficial rather than disastrous. For example killing 10,000 elephants because we thought they were killing grassland in Africa turned out to be a really dumb idea. American settlers accidentally killing rocky mountain locust populations in the 1800's turned out to be extremely advantageous for growing food the next 200 years. So it is indeed possible to mess with nature and have a positive outcome.

I didn't get past 2:04 in this presentation before I became extremely concerned verging on alarm and regardless of further content could not wait, to express my anxieties.

When I was younger and even more ignorant than I am now, the prospect of exterminating an irritating pest would not have merited a second thought.

No more itchy Mozzie, sand fly or midge (noseeum) bites? Great!

Now however the mere possibility for deliberate, methodic extermination of an entire species of higher organism?

Is horrifying.

Given, that it is impossible to quantify what is not known and certainty that our ignorance profoundly outweighs our knowledge, the implications? Are appalling!

All, creatures in our biosphere are interdependent to some extent in a plethora of contexts from nourishment and reproduction to habitation and stimuli for adaptation.

We are still far from identifying all the life forms with which we share the precious, fragile, blue-green jewel we rely upon for life particularly, with regard to the oceans.

So how can any true scientist possibly claim to understand much less presume qualification to evaluate likely consequences for all species potentially affected by essentially clumsy, ignorant meddling?

Crustaceans like crabs, prawns and lobsters are essentially aquatic cousins of terrestrial insects and that consideration also encompasses many species of plankton such as krill.

Krill is a tiny, shrimp like creature upon which a majority of the mighty and majestic whale species are utterly dependent for sustenance so to unintentionally eradiate them would exterminate most of the Cetaceans.

Carnivores like dolphins, porpoises, seals depend upon plankton because fish and mollusks are dependent upon it.

Coral polyps, are also plankton feeders.

Creatures such as sharks and carnivorous whales prey upon seals and penguins so if they disappear so do the other species.

Hopefully anybody who had not given the subject sufficient thought can now appreciate how a cascade effect alluded to by extermination of mosquito's could and would probably proceed!

Mosquito's and their larvae are an important if not vital link in the food chain for a number of freshwater species such as Dragon flies, water spiders, amphibians and fish.

Eradicate mosquitos and you eradicate mosquito larvae which, when subject to a balance of probabilities, will almost certainly incur a disastrous cascade effect throughout the food chain.


Small fish eat mosquito larvae, Dragon fly larvae eat small fish, Dragon flies and some varieties of small birds eat mosquito's and larger bird's and species like spiders eat dragonflies and even small birds.

It is highly appropriate to include a brief and ancient poem by an unknown author as emphasis for the applicable principle.

For want of a nail (mosquito) the shoe (larvae) was lost.
For want of a shoe the horse was lost.
For want of a horse the rider was lost.
For want of a rider the battle was lost.
For want of a battle the kingdom (of man) was lost.
And all for the want of a horseshoe nail. (mosquito)

As callous as it sounds to anybody inclined to anthropomorphize regarding statistics for global mortality we, have no right to interfere with nature in any much less a profound way including, 'genetic modification' of plants!

The world is being slowly poisoned due to an appalling range of toxins produced by massively unsustainable levels of humanity and attempts to economically sustain that population are currently the rationale for genetic modification.

The incidence of afflictions such as gluten and lactose sensitivity and intolerance are on the increase along with cancer and other systemic dysfunctions and may, quite possibly, be linked to genetic modification of staple foods although nobody in a position to do so is going to admit it.

Many such identities are instead profiting by developing remedies for disorders which once were not of concern on anything like the scale they currently and increasingly are.

Rather than focusing on reducing human population levels and thus saving our dying planet, science has instead long focused on un-naturally prolonging the human life span.

Not only is science doing this via longevity research but also by remedy and prevention of multifarious afflictions which serve at naturally limiting the population of any species.

So far as is discernible from available evidence humanity is the only species that has ever developed a capacity for modifying our environment to more than an inconsequential extent.

Consequently we, have become an improbable apex predator according to the normal métier by which nature used to reconcile a natural hierarchy.

Even in the extremely, unlikely event that we could ever learn to replicate life in it's current forms much less improve upon it, that would not bestow upon us a right to intentionally destroy any, naturally occurring higher form of life.

It is arguable that since we have reached a juncture where contemplating this monstrous proposition can even be entertained in theory we, have outgrown our birthplace and need to either change or leave.

If we do not amend our ways yet do not leave by artificial means at which we are increasingly accomplished either, it is increasingly likely we will ultimately do so by natural extinction and take the bulk of our cohabitants with us.

Creatures possessing complex structure are far more improbable and fragile than any of their microbial nemeses but so far nobody has claimed much less demonstrated an ability to replicate even an amoeba from scratch.

As far as is generally known we are still so far from the latter achievement it is mercifully currently beyond the realm of possibility.

The COVID pandemic is drastically eloquent substantiation for just how dangerously incompetent our best efforts at meddling with life currently are yet somebody, is actually contemplating a species genocide using such methods?

We choose which delusions we want to follow. Some delusions have more potential than others to enhance the human experience. It could be the delusion of fame and fortune, or that science will fix everything for us, or that we need law and religion to be ethical, or that you are god incarnate. Which delusions cage your mind and which free it? One thing I feel is real is that we are not merely visitors here, not only part of this reality, we are in fact the universe, experiencing itself as individuals. Everything that exists adding its unique conscious perspective. The elements of our bodies were forged in the stars, yet our consciousness is somehow not our body. And how awesome it is to get the human experience! Allowing us to share in great detail our individual perspectives and experiences, being able to imagine the infinite potential we, as life on earth, have yet to realize. The delusion I choose to follow is that we will collectively understand that we as humanity, are the ones that choose the quality of our world. The only thing holding us back is ourselves. We can choose to doubt ourselves or to believe in our limitless potential. Our reality seems to bend toward what we think and express. So I choose to imagine and speak of a utopian future, all living things in harmony and balance, learning from the intelligence of evolution to advance and create ideas and technology to make life more enjoyable for all of us equally, to protect life from existential threats. I would much rather be a nobody in that world than a winner of this competitive world. We choose.
